docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have found that some newborns partial to the taste of salt already have blood pressure higher than normal, a discovery that may offer doctors a tool to identify those at risk for hypertension. Most babies exhibit an aversion to salty tastes. But writing in Hypertension, the American Heart Association journal, researchers said they had found that those babies who seemed to like salt and who had a least one grandparent with a history of high blood pressure, had blood pressure readings that were somewhat higher than those of other babies.
docs.abstract: Researchers, led by Mount Auburn Hospital chairman of medicine Dr Stephen Zinner, in study in Hypertension, find that some newborns partial to taste of salt and who have at least one grandparent with history of hypertension have higher-than-normal blood pressure readings; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers have found that some newborns partial to the taste of salt already have blood pressure higher than normal, a discovery that may offer doctors a tool to identify those at risk for hypertension.    Most babies exhibit an aversion to salty...

docs.lead_paragraph: It is well established that black people with colon cancer are more likely to die of it than white people are, but researchers have been unable to explain why. A new study offers evidence that, its authors say, refutes theories that biological differences between the races may play a role. When black and white colon cancer patients are given the same access to chemotherapy, the researchers say, the survival rates are almost exactly the same. The lead author of the study, Dr. A. David McCollum, and his colleagues report the findings in the current issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute.
docs.abstract: Study conducted by Drs A David McCollum and Charles S Fuchs, published in Journal of the National Cancer Institute, refutes theories that racial differences may play role in colon cancer survival rates; finds rates are nearly identical in blacks and whites who are given same access to chemotherapy after surgery (M)
docs.snippet: It is well established that black people with colon cancer are more likely to die of it than white people are, but researchers have been unable to explain why. A new study offers evidence that, its authors say, refutes theories that biological...

docs.lead_paragraph: Natural disasters usually come rife with drama. Hurricanes, tornadoes, forest fires, earthquakes -- all make for good headlines and even better visuals. But it would be hard to make a blockbuster movie about a heat wave. Heat waves come on subtly, raising summer temperatures just a little higher than normal and then receding. But they kill more people in the United States than all other natural disasters combined.

headline.main: Most Deadly of the Natural Disasters: The Heat Wave

docs.abstract: Article on deadliest of natural disasters: heat wave; University of Delaware's Center for Climatic Research reports average of 1,500 American city dwellers die annually because of heat while annual death toll from tornadoes, earthquakes and floods combined is fewer than 200; Chicago's July 1995 heat wave, which claimed 739 lives, recalled; photos; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Natural disasters usually come rife with drama. Hurricanes, tornadoes, forest fires, earthquakes -- all make for good headlines and even better visuals.    But it would be hard to make a blockbuster movie about a heat wave. Heat waves come on subtly,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Emergency room doctors may be too quick with the needle and thread, a new study suggests. In many cases, it adds, just washing out a cut and bandaging it achieves the same results as sutures. The study, in the current issue of The British Medical Journal, looked just at hand injuries. The authors said the findings could be applicable to any cut that is not in a cosmetically sensitive area like the face and does not involve a gaping wound or damage to tendons or nerves.
docs.abstract: Study led by University of California at San Francisco emergency medicine doctor James Quinn, published in British Medical Journal, concludes washing out and bandaging cuts achieves same results as sutures in hand injury cases; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: No one looks forward to spring more than people with seasonal affective disorder, who grow depressed in the waning light of winter. A smaller group of people, however, suffer on the opposite side of the calendar. Consider Violet Adair, a 39-year-old artist in Oakland, Calif., who gets ready for summer by filling plastic bottles with water. ''I'll put them in my freezer and I'll sleep with them,'' she said. ''I'll sleep hugging a two-liter Pepsi bottle filled with ice.''

headline.main: Seasonal Depression Can Accompany Summer Sun

docs.abstract: Article on summer SAD, also known as reverse seasonal affective disorder, in which people become depressed during summer; about 5 percent of adult Americans are thought to have winter variation but fewer than 1 percent, usually women in their reproductive years, have summer SAD; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Conquering Rheumatoid Arthritis,'' by Dr. Thomas F. Lee, Prometheus Books, $20. In the prime of his creative life, Renoir ''unwittingly entered a world of inexorable progressive disability.'' The disability was rheumatoid arthritis, a painful and crippling disease that has plagued millions of people for thousands of years.

headline.main: New Promise For Treating A Crippler

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book Conquering Rheumatoid Arthritis by Dr Thomas F Lee; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The idea that people with H.I.V. should take steps to prevent passing along the infection may seem self-evident. But health officials have long understood that a host of factors -- stress, a craving for intimacy, fear of rejection, drug and alcohol abuse -- can cause lapses in judgment and self-restraint that lead people to have unsafe sex. So AIDS educators, alarmed at the continuing spread of H.I.V., have now added a crucial weapon to their prevention arsenal: educational campaigns encouraging infected people to take responsibility for not transmitting the virus.

headline.main: New Tactic To Prevent AIDS Spread

docs.abstract: AIDS educators, alarmed at continuing spread of HIV and acknowledging that traditional prevention approach to AIDS has become less effective, are embarking on new campaigns to encourage infected people to take responsiblity for not transmitting the virus; opponents say ad campaigns make scapegoats of those with virus; campaign supporters say vast majority of prevention efforts still focus on those who are not infected (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When lesser measures can no longer control the pain and disability of arthritic knees, surgery to reconstruct or replace them then becomes a consideration. But only a consideration. These are entirely elective procedures, and anyone who is a candidate for either would be wise to know in advance just what they involve, both during the surgery and for months afterward, and what limitations on athletic activities are likely afterward.

headline.main: New Knees May Be in Order When Other Options Fail

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health article on knee replacement or reconstruction surgery; describes both procedures; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The barrage of images and stories depicting doctors battling death have become standard fare today. Even the doors of the operating room, once the exclusive domain of surgeons, have been thrown wide open. Every day, millions watch lifesaving operations on television, both dramatic representations and actual procedures. Consequently, it is difficult for the 21st century observer to imagine the shock and revulsion Thomas Eakins provoked when unveiling his portraits of surgery, ''The Gross Clinic'' in 1876 and ''The Agnew Clinic'' in 1889.

headline.main: From Eakins's Canvas, 1800's Version of Medical Docudrama

docs.abstract: Article on portraits of surgery, shocking for their time, done by Thomas Eakins in 1870's and 1880's; surgery paintings and more than 150 other Eakins works are on view at Metropolitan Museum of Art; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Insufficient levels of potassium may put people at a higher risk of strokes, especially if they are taking diuretics, researchers report today. If the theory is proven, some people may be able to reduce the danger of strokes by just changing their diets. The study, in the journal Neurology, followed 5,600 men and women 65 and older from four to eight years. After keeping track of which people had strokes, the lead author, Dr. Deborah M. Green of the Queen's Medical Center in Honolulu, and her colleagues found that potassium appeared to have a role.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Honolulu's Queen's Medical Center, in study published in journal Neurology, find that insufficient levels of potassium may put people, particularly those taking diuretics, at higher risk of strokes; suggest danger may be reduced by changing diet and that doctors monitor patients' potassium levels; drawing (M)
